metadata.case_name: Appellant (Lady Doctor) v. State of Rajasthan

facts.text: Appellant appointed by Local Self-Government Department, Government of Rajasthan by order dated 27.11.1974 as Lady Doctor under Municipal Council, Ganganagar on purely temporary basis for six months or till candidate selected by Rajasthan Public Service Commission (RPSC) is available, whichever earlier.
Appointment made under Section 308 of Rajasthan Municipalities Act, 1959 read with Rules 26 and 27 of Rajasthan Municipal Service Rules, 1963.
Appellant's working period continued to be extended by orders of Local Self-Government Department.
Appellant selected by RPSC in October 1976 and August 1982 but did not join pursuant to such selection.
Appellant's services terminated on 1.10.1988 on ground that candidate selected by RPSC was available.
Appellant filed writ petition No. 3739 of 1988 before Rajasthan High Court challenging termination.
Rajasthan High Court passed interim stay order on 12.10.1988 directing that appellant not to be relieved.
Interim order made absolute by Rajasthan High Court on 21.3.1989.

Learned Single Judge of Rajasthan High Court by judgment dated 5.3.1993 held termination illegal as ignoring 14 years service, directed authorities to adjudge suitability within one month and regularize services with all benefits.
State of Rajasthan filed appeal before Division Bench of Rajasthan High Court; appellant allowed to continue in service per interim orders.
Division Bench of Rajasthan High Court by impugned judgment dated 11.4.1997 held appellant continued as temporary employee under Rule 27, no right to hold post.
By time of Supreme Court appeal, appellant had put in 28 years service (14 years pre-termination + 14 years per interim directions).

Appellant given privileges under Gratuity and Pension Fund Benefit Schemes under Rajasthan Municipal Services (Pension) Rules, 1989; applied for voluntary retirement nearly two years back without final decision.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant's termination from service is in order, or whether long continuous service confers right to regularization despite temporary appointment under Rule 27.
Whether principles of legitimate expectation apply to claim permanency or regularization.

petitioner_arguments.text: Initial appointment conditional but long service (28 years) assumed permanency; Single Judge justified in directing regularization.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Director, Institute of Management Development, U.P. vs. Pushpa Srivastava (1992) 4 SCC 33; Ashwani Kumar vs. State of Bihar JT 1997 (1) SC 243; Daily Rated Casual Labour vs. Union of India (1988) 1 SCC 122; Narender Chadha vs. Union of India (1986) 2 SCC 157; State of Haryana vs. Ram Diya (1990) 2 SCR 431; State of U.P. vs. Dr. Deep Narain Tripathi (1996) 8 SCC 454

petitioner_arguments.text: Benefits under Pension Rules cannot be denied; applied for voluntary retirement.

respondent_arguments.text: Appointment temporary with clear condition to terminate if RPSC candidate available; appellant did not join when selected twice; no enforceable right or lien despite long service.

court_reasoning.text: Appointment under Rule 27 temporary; no continuation beyond one year without RPSC concurrence; terminated when RPSC candidate available; no automatic extension or presumption of concurrence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Nature of employment clearly temporary; no scope for regularization without proper selection by RPSC.

court_reasoning.text: Precedents distinguished as rendered in different factual backgrounds; ad-hoc cannot be replaced by another ad-hoc, only by regularly selected; availability of RPSC candidate key, not joining.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Initial recruitment must be regularized through prescribed agency.

court_reasoning.text: No legitimate expectation as no representation or waiver of conditions; mere continuance does not create impression of waiver; clear statutory rules override.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Principle of legitimate expectation not applicable without reliance on representation and detriment.

holdings.text: Termination valid; no right to regularization or permanency based on long service in temporary capacity.
Principle of legitimate expectation has no application.

precedents_cited.case_name: Director, Institute of Management Development, U.P. vs. Pushpa Srivastava
precedents_cited.relevance: Relied by petitioner for regularization on long service

precedents_cited.case_name: Ashwani Kumar Ors. vs. State of Bihar Ors.
Daily Rated Casual Labour Employed under P&T Department vs. Union of India
Narender Chadha and Ors. vs. Union of India
State of Haryana and Anr. vs. Ram Diya
State of U.P. and Ors. vs. Dr. Deep Narain Tripathi
J K Public Service Commission and Ors. vs. Dr. Narinder Mohan
precedents_cited.relevance: No general rule for regularization of long ad-hoc service; rules not to be relaxed

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Haryana v. Piara Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Ad-hoc/temporary to be replaced by regularly selected; consider regularization if eligible but not general rule

precedents_cited.case_name: Union of India and Ors. vs. Harish Balkrishna Mahajan

statutes_cited.name: Rajasthan Municipalities Act, 1959
statutes_cited.relevance: Power of appointment exercised under this section read with Rules

statutes_cited.name: Rajasthan Municipal Service Rules, 1963
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs temporary appointments, probation, confirmation; no continuation beyond one year without RPSC concurrence

statutes_cited.name: Rajasthan Municipal Services (Pension) Rules, 1989
statutes_cited.relevance: Privileges granted to appellant under Gratuity and Pension schemes

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld Division Bench judgment; termination valid as temporary appointment under Rule 27; no regularization or legitimate expectation; appeal dismissed.

key_quotes.text: The only point involved in this appeal is whether the appellants termination from service is in order.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: No appointment made under sub-rule (1) shall be continued beyond a period of one year without referring it to the Commission for their concurrence and shall be terminated immediately on their refusal to concur.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key rule interpretation defeating regularization claim

key_quotes.text: A decision is an authority for what it decides and not for what can be inferred from the conclusion.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The inevitable conclusion is that Division Bench judgment is on terra firma and needs no interference.
key_quotes.speaker: court
